title: Are there many people who regret going to Oxford and Cambridge? - Quora
tags: Colleges and Universities in the United Kingdom

response.answer_text: Yes, actually there are. Lots. That is, at least in my course, Mathematics, Cambridge. There are several reasons for this. The level of the course is insanely more difficult than almost any other Maths course in the UK (with a couple of exceptions such as, obviously, Oxford). And this reflects on the grades: an average 2.2 from Cambridge Maths Tripos would be roughly equivalent to an average First in most Universities in terms of skills and effort. This looks bad in CVs, I'm told. Why going to Cambridge and getting a 2.2 when you could be in the top 20 of your year at another Universitiy? Furthermore, the focus of the course is almost entirely academic: even the most “real-life sounding" courses have a completely theoretical flavor and massively industry-unfriendly. Economics, programming : we do not really have those. Even in terms of networking, corresponding courses in universities such as Imperial or LSE have by far more opportunities for you to get involved with potential employers, non-academic projects and so on. Our course focused mostly on academic networking rather than industrial. So why even bother going to Cambridge? Yeah sure, you have the prestige and all, but I am not convinced that this is enough to counter the significantly lower grade. The real reason is the following: some of us actually like maths. We think they are fun and we think that Cambridge Maths are the most fun ones in the country. We are weird. I know. But we do. We love them. In conclusion: If you do not absolutely adore Maths, stay away from Cambridge's CMS. You do not necessarily need to want to stay in academia - although it’s a huge plus. But you do need to care about the subject deeply. Otherwise you probably have more suitable options. Again, this is just for Mathematics. I don't really remember what was going on with other courses. Edit: paragraph about networking rephrased. See comments. Edit 2: First Paragraph rephrased.

One of my best friends regrets studying economics at Cambridge. He’s a very bright guy but probably below average for Cambridge. Consequently he emerged with a 2.2 and really struggled to get a job as many employers have a blanket 2.1 and above policy and don’t get that someone who gets a 2.2 at Cambridge would get a 2.1 or first virtually anywhere else

I don’t think there would be many of my generation (Oxford BA 1972, Cambridge PhD 1978) because we didn’t have to pay much, if anything, for the privilege. I consider myself incredibly fortunate. It might be different in more recent times if students didn’t feel they were getting value for money. But I seriously doubt there would be many even so.

For languages, yes. They are usually manoeuvred towards teaching often in private schools and find other career options quite limited. I was able to go to a French Grande Ecole during my sandwich year thus I ended up with both better French and more career options upon graduation. I declined an offer from Cambridge for this reason.
